text.headline:
Vortex
2005 - 2015
text.text: Vortex is a little story of success. Today, 10 years after its foundation by two PhD in Atmospheric Physics and a self-taught IT expert, the company has presence in 3 continents and serves users from 150 countries

media.caption: Pep Moreno, Vortex CEO, installing a met. mast during a measurement campaign in Northern Spain. Early 90’s

text.headline: A young company made up of old experts
text.text: Vortex was born in Barcelona on September 19, 2005 but its team’s background is much older. The accumulated experience in the wind industry of its members goes back 25 years

media.caption: David Saez, IT Director, at Vortex computer cluster. Early 2006

text.headline: All started with a simple, powerful idea
text.text: The foundational approach of the Vortex service was simple: remote atmospheric modeling launched on-line. With the aim to 'bring the power of a supercomputer to your fingerprints' in mind, our first computer cluster was set up in 2006

media.caption: Professor Josep Calbó, Scientific Advisor, returning from the University of Girona with his, at that time 2 years old, daughter. Late 2006

text.headline: Research that faces the real world
text.text: We love research. Half of Vortex employees hold a PhD and we keep active links with several research institutes since our first collaboration with the University of Girona in 2006. However, the continuos feedback from our users makes us always keep research tight to real world 'imperfections'

media.caption: One of the first drafts of Vortex Interface. Early 2007

text.headline:
Complex modeling at
one-click distance
text.text: From its first sketches in 2007, the philosophy of Vortex Interface was to reduce the complexity of the atmospherice modeling down to intuitive website user actions. Since the beginning, user manuals and courses were strictly forbiden

media.caption: Pau Casso, Technical Director, at Longs Peak (Colorado) after attending the 9th WRF Users' Workshop in Boulder. July 2008

text.headline: A cloud (service) with solid foundations
text.text: Vortex is not a large-sized company but we are not at all alone. Since our first compilation of the WRF model, Vortex core technology relies on a collaborative code developed through the effort of a community of over 23,000 registered users

media.caption: Gil Lizcano, R & D Director, at University of Oxford. Mid 2009

text.headline: Growing slow but safe
text.text: By the time of our first sale in 2009, original Vortex portfolio included only 3 products. Current Wind & Site, Solar and Forecast ones compile 10. Development and test of new products has been treated with great care by Vortex R & D department to ensure robustness of the service

text.headline: The eruption of the Eyjafjallajökul
text.text: The ashes expelled by this Icelandic volcano on April 2010 affected the activities of the population in Europe and across the world. There was extensive air travel disruption caused by the closure of airspace... (source: Wikipedia)

media.caption: Receiving the 'Eyjafjallajökul' award from EWEA's COO, Bruce Douglas, during the conference dinner in Warsaw. April 22, 2010

text.headline: Caravan to the East
text.text: EWEC 2010 in Warsaw was going to be our first EWEA annual event as exhibitors but the eruption of the Eyjafjallajökul did not allow us to fly. Without thinking twice, we drove up there in a motorhome. The 2,400 km traveled to Poland made us worthy of the prize (a bottle of vodka) to the participants driving from further

media.caption: Jordi Ferrer, Managing and Financial Director, and Pep Moreno in Vortex partners offices in Beijing. Late 2010

text.headline: 患难识知己<sup>*</sup>
text.text:
Starting in China in 2010, expansion of Vortex to Asia has been based on collaborations with local partners. With offices also in India and Turkey, they are now our gate to the East
* A friend in need is a friend indeed

media.caption: German Delgado, Commercial Director, in Rio de Janeiro. Early 2011

text.headline: Emerging in the Emergents
text.text: Besides the European countries, Brasil, India, China, South Africa... have been priority Vortex targets since as early as 2011

media.caption: First Vortex office in Brussels. Late 2011

text.headline: Natural born glocal
text.text: Wind does not understand about borders, so does not Vortex team. By opening first satellite office in Brussels in 2011, we strengthed our presence in Europe

media.caption: Elies Campmany, at Vortex computer cluster in Barcelona. Early 2012

text.headline: Run #10,000
text.text: Vortex computer cluster never sleeps. In the middle of (our) night in 2012, a Korean user launched Run #10,000. Three years later, Run #63,000 has been reached last summer

media.caption: Vortex flags planted at EWEA's annual event in Viena. February 2013

text.headline: Involved in European wind industry research
text.text: Chairing EWEA's annual event sessions, collaborating with DTU or TPWind, are a couple of examples of Vortex commitment with European wind industry R & D initiatives

media.caption: Abel Tortosa, Forecast Director, at EWEA's Wind Power Forecasting workshop in Rotterdam. December 2013

text.headline: Looking ahead and beyond
text.text: While Wind & Site products refer only to the Past, extending Vortex modeling service to the Future was a natural step. Vortex Forecasting service was launched in 2013, not restricted to the short-term but looking beyond within the Seasonal-to-Decadal Climate Prediction SPECS project

media.caption: Ed Montero, Manager Director Vortex FdC inc., in Miami. April 2014

text.headline: The land of the free and the home of the brave
text.text: Our presence in US dates back to AWEA's annual event of Dallas but it hasn't been permanent until the inauguration of a Vortex office in Florida in April 2014

media.caption: Alex Montornés and Josep Calbó at the 5th International Conference on Meteorology and Climatology of the Mediterranean in Istanbul. Late 2014

text.headline: Citizens of the State-of-the-Art
text.text: In-house R & D is one of the aspects which Vortex invest more resources in. Advanced tests of WRF-LES, started in 2014, is one example. Working to be always on the cutting-edge of our fields of specialization is the only way a small, agile company can survive

text.headline: Vortex modest contributions to the Common Good
text.text: During summer 2015, our company joined the ECG movement, an organisation devoted to the change of the Economical paradigm in benefit of the Common Good. Earlier this year, our Director of Hapiness received the Innovative Company in Conciliation and Time Prize awarding our corporate policy regarding Vortex own employees Good

media.caption: Patricia Puig, Vortex Solar and Hapiness Director. June 2015

text.headline: Here comes the Sun
text.text: June 2015, Intersolar Munich: debut of Vortex Solar service in the major industry event of the sector in Europe. Our first excursion outside the Wind industry but with the same base and approach succesfully used until now

media.caption: The Vortex team walking by the seashore during the 10th anniversary in Empuries, September 2015

text.headline: Next step, future
text.text: In September 2015 we celebrated Vortex anniversary in the delicious corner were ancient Greeks first landed in our coast. A encouraging meeting to charge energy for the next 10 years to come
